title: Blue Origin
content:
{{Short description|American aerospace and spaceflight company}}
{{Use American English|date=July 2021}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2021}}
{{Infobox company
| name = Blue Origin, LLC
| logo = Blue Origin new logo.svg
| image = Blue Origin Feather.svg
| image_caption = Feather logo
| type = [[Limited liability company]]
| industry = [[Aerospace industry|Aerospace]]
| founded = {{start date and age|September 8, 2000}}
| founder = [[Jeff Bezos]]
| hq_location_city = [[Kent, Washington|Kent]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]]
| hq_location_country = U.S.
| key_people = Bob Smith ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]])<ref>{{Cite web |last=Sheetz |first=Michael |date=April 18, 2018 |title=Blue Origin's new rocket engine will be able to launch '100 full missions,' CEO says |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/04/18/blue-origin-ceo-bob-smith-be-4-will-be-able-to-launch-100-missions.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190527132002/https://www.cnbc.com/2018/04/18/blue-origin-ceo-bob-smith-be-4-will-be-able-to-launch-100-missions.html |archive-date=May 27, 2019 |access-date=October 9, 2018 |website=Cnbc.com}}</ref>
| owner = Jeff Bezos
| num_employees = 6,000<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.ffxnow.com/2022/07/08/jeff-bezos-space-flight-company-blue-origin-has-its-reston-landing-spot/ |title=Jeff Bezos' space flight company Blue Origin has its Reston landing spot |date=July 8, 2022 |work=FFXnow |first=Matt |last=Blitz}}</ref>
| num_employees_year = 2022
| website = {{URL|https://www.blueorigin.com/|BlueOrigin.com}}

{{Private spaceflight}}
'''Blue Origin, LLC''' is an American [[private spaceflight|privately funded]] [[aerospace manufacturer]] and [[sub-orbital spaceflight]] services company headquartered in [[Kent, Washington]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin LLC {{!}} Financial Times |url=https://www.ft.com/stream/dbbe7df6-3893-4bed-ba7d-1f935caa055d |access-date=October 6, 2020 |website=www.ft.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin LLC – Company Profile and News |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/profile/company/5043517Z:US |access-date=October 6, 2020 |website=Bloomberg.com}}</ref> Founded in 2000 by [[Jeff Bezos]], the founder and executive chairman of [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]], the company is led by CEO Bob Smith and aims to make access to space cheaper and more reliable through reusable launch vehicles.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Staff Reporter |date=January 24, 2019 |title=Kent's Blue Origin racks up another successful New Shepard launch into space |url=https://www.kentreporter.com/business/kents-blue-origin-racks-up-another-successful-new-shepard-launch-into-space/ |access-date=October 3, 2020 |website=Kent Reporter |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Berger |first=Eric |date=April 2, 2016 |title=Why Blue Origin's latest launch is a huge deal for cheap space access |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2016/04/why-blue-origins-latest-launch-is-a-huge-deal-for-cheap-space-access/ |access-date=October 3, 2020 |website=Ars Technica |language=en-us}}</ref> [[Rob Meyerson]] led Blue Origin from 2003 to 2017 and served as its first president.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |date=November 8, 2018 |title=Former Blue Origin president Rob Meyerson leaves Jeff Bezos' space venture |url=https://www.geekwire.com/2018/veteran-aerospace-engineer-rob-meyerson-leaves-jeff-bezos-blue-origin-space-venture/ |access-date=April 16, 2021 |website=GeekWire |language=en-US}}</ref> Blue Origin is employing an incremental approach from suborbital to [[orbital flight]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aero-news.net/index.cfm?do=main.textpost&id=853c2364-ee99-4c67-86ef-d9d219416fdf|title=Blue Origin NS-21 Mission Nears Launch|date=June 3, 2022|publisher=Aero-News Network|access-date=December 15, 2022}}</ref> with each developmental step building on its prior work.<ref name="ars20210301" /> The company's name refers to the blue planet, [[Earth]], as the point of origin.<ref name="motto">{{Cite news|date=October 25, 2016|title=Gradatim Ferociter! Jeff Bezos explains Blue Origin's motto, logo … and the boots|language=en-US|work=GeekWire|url=https://www.geekwire.com/2016/jeff-bezos-blue-origin-motto-logo-boots/|url-status=live|access-date=January 25, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180121170518/https://www.geekwire.com/2016/jeff-bezos-blue-origin-motto-logo-boots/|archive-date=January 21, 2018}}</ref>

Blue Origin develops orbital technology, rocket-powered [[VTVL|vertical takeoff and vertical landing]] (VTVL) vehicles for access to [[sub-orbital spaceflight|suborbital]] and [[orbital spaceflight|orbital]] [[outer space|space]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin |url=http://www.blueorigin.com |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206013801/http://blueorigin.com/ |archive-date=December 6, 2013 |access-date=December 5, 2013 |publisher=Blue Origin}}</ref> Initially focused on [[suborbital spaceflight]], the company has designed, built and flown multiple testbeds of its [[New Shepard]] vehicle at its [[Blue Origin facilities|facilities]] in [[Culberson County, Texas]]. Developmental [[flight testing|test flight]]s of the [[New Shepard]],<ref>{{Cite news |title=Blue Origin Engineer Talks Next Steps for New Shepard, New Glenn |work=Space.com |url=https://www.space.com/38327-blue-origin-engineer-talks-next-steps.html |url-status=live |access-date=January 25, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180126070628/https://www.space.com/38327-blue-origin-engineer-talks-next-steps.html |archive-date=January 26, 2018}}</ref> named after the first American in space, [[Alan Shepard]], began in April 2015, and flight testing is ongoing.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Grush |first=Loren |date=December 10, 2019 |title=Blue Origin successfully launches and lands its New Shepard rocket during 12th overall test flight |url=https://www.theverge.com/2019/12/10/21003756/blue-origin-new-shepard-rocket-test-launch-science-research-watch-live |access-date=August 7, 2020 |website=The Verge |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin moves closer to human spaceflight with 12th New Shepard launch |url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2019/12/11/blue-origin-moves-closer-to-human-spaceflight-with-12th-new-shepard-launch/ |access-date=August 7, 2020 |website=TechCrunch |language=en-US}}</ref> Blue Origin rescheduled the original 2018 date for first passengers several times, and eventually successfully flew its first crewed mission on July 20, 2021.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Jeff Bezos Says Blue Origin Will Put People in Space in 2019 |work=Fortune |url=http://fortune.com/2018/09/19/bezos-blue-origin-people-in-space-2019/ |url-status=live |access-date=January 23, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190123223405/http://fortune.com/2018/09/19/bezos-blue-origin-people-in-space-2019/ |archive-date=January 23, 2019}}</ref> It has not yet begun commercial passenger flights, nor announced a firm date for when they would begin. On nearly every one of the test flights since 2015, the uncrewed vehicle has reached a test altitude of more than {{convert|100|km|ft|sp=us}} and achieved a top speed of more than [[Mach number|Mach]] 3, reaching space above the [[Kármán line]], with both the [[space capsule]] and its [[rocket]] [[Booster (rocketry)|booster]] successfully [[Soft landing (rocketry)|soft landing]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Palmer |first=Katie |title=Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin Rocket Took Off and Landed – Again |url=https://www.wired.com/2016/01/jeff-bezos-blue-origin-rocket-took-off-and-landed-again/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123162751/http://www.wired.com/2016/01/jeff-bezos-blue-origin-rocket-took-off-and-landed-again/ |archive-date=January 23, 2016 |access-date=January 22, 2016 |magazine=Wired |publisher=Wired.com}}</ref>

Blue Origin moved into the [[orbital spaceflight]] technology [[new product development|development]] business in 2014, initially as a [[rocket engine]] supplier for others via a contractual agreement to build a new large rocket engine, the [[BE-4]], for major US launch system operator [[United Launch Alliance]] (ULA). Blue said the "BE-4 would be 'ready for flight' by 2017."<ref name=ars20210805/> By 2015, Blue Origin had announced plans to also manufacture and fly its own orbital [[launch vehicle]], known as the [[New Glenn]], from the [[Florida Space Coast]]. {{nowrap|BE-4}} had been expected to complete engine qualification testing by late 2018.<ref name=sn20180419/> However, by August 2021, the flight engines for ULA have still not been qualified, and [[Ars Technica]] revealed in an in-depth article serious technical and managerial problems in the BE-4 program.<ref name=ars20210805/>

In May 2019, Jeff Bezos unveiled Blue Origin's vision for space and also plans for a moon lander known as "[[Blue Moon (spacecraft)|Blue Moon]]",<ref>{{Cite news |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |date=May 9, 2019 |title=Jeff Bezos Unveils Blue Origin's Vision for Space, and a Moon Lander |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/09/science/jeff-bezos-moon.html |url-status=live |access-date=May 10, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190510110122/https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/09/science/jeff-bezos-moon.html |archive-date=May 10, 2019 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> set to be ready by 2024.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Jeff Bezos aims Blue Origin at the Moon |url=http://social.techcrunch.com/2019/05/09/jeff-bezos-aims-blue-origin-at-the-moon/ |access-date=May 29, 2019 |website=TechCrunch |language=en-US}}</ref> On July 20, 2021, Blue Origin sent its [[Blue Origin NS-16|first crewed mission]] into space via its New Shepard rocket and spaceflight system. The flight was approximately 10 minutes, and crossed the [[Kármán line]]. Bezos was part of the four member crew along with his brother [[Mark Bezos]], [[Wally Funk]], and [[Oliver Daemen]].

== History ==
{{Cleanup section|reason=[[WP:PROSELINE]].|date=July 2021}}[[File:Blue Origin Coat of Arms.png|thumb|The coat of arms of Blue Origin]]
[[File:Blue Origin Incremental Development (Spacecraft).jpg|thumb|Blue Origin's three vehicles as of late 2012: (1) Goddard subscale demonstrator, flight tested in 2006–2007, (2) early, subscale version of the suborbital New Shepard propulsion module (as flown in 2011; variations exist to the larger New Shepard that actually flew in 2015), (3) future Space Vehicle (on top of a future orbital launch vehicle which, when stacked, is Blue Origin's future Orbital Transportation System).<ref>{{Cite web |date=January 9, 2013 |title=NasaTelevision: Commercial Crew Progress Status Update |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IvVdD6qqROM |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108122553/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IvVdD6qqROM |archive-date=January 8, 2016 |access-date=December 5, 2013 |publisher=Youtube.com}}</ref>]]

Blue Origin founder Jeff Bezos has been interested in space from an early age. A profile published in 2013 described a 1982 ''[[Miami Herald]]'' interview Bezos gave after he was named valedictorian of his high school class. The 18-year-old Bezos said he wanted "to build space hotels, amusement parks and colonies for 2 million or 3 million people who would be in orbit.  'The whole idea is to preserve the Earth' he told the newspaper ...  The goal was to be able to evacuate humans. The planet would become a park."<ref name="wp20130810">{{Cite news |last=Whoriskey |first=Peter |date=August 11, 2013 |title=For Jeff Bezos, a new frontier |newspaper=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/for-bezos-the-post-represents-new-frontier/2013/08/10/ba7cfeb6-013c-11e3-9a3e-916de805f65d_story.html |url-status=live |access-date=October 3, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170916053753/https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/for-bezos-the-post-represents-new-frontier/2013/08/10/ba7cfeb6-013c-11e3-9a3e-916de805f65d_story.html |archive-date=September 16, 2017}}</ref>

In 1999, after watching the rocketry biopic film ''[[October Sky]]'', Bezos discussed forming a space company with science-fiction author [[Neal Stephenson]].<ref>{{Cite book |last=Davenport |first=Christian |title=The Space Barons: Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos, and the Quest to Colonize the Cosmos |publisher=PublicAffairs, an imprint owned by Hachette Book Group |year=2018 |isbn=978-1610398299}}</ref><ref name="TSR-2018-03-26">{{Cite magazine |last=Jeff Foust |date=March 26, 2018 |title=Reviews: Rocket Billionaires and The Space Barons |url=http://www.thespacereview.com/article/3457/1 |url-status=live |magazine=The Space Review |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180401144442/http://www.thespacereview.com/article/3457/1 |archive-date=April 1, 2018 |access-date=April 1, 2018}}</ref> Blue Origin was founded in 2000 in [[Kent, Washington]], and began [[new product development|developing]] both [[rocket propulsion]] systems and [[launch vehicle]]s.<ref name="sir20170414">{{Cite news |last=de Selding |first=Peter B. |date=April 14, 2017 |title=Blue Origin's older than SpaceX in more ways than one |work=Space Intel Report |url=https://www.spaceintelreport.com/blue-origins-older-than-spacex-in-more-ways-than-one |url-status=live |access-date=April 15, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170416044845/https://www.spaceintelreport.com/blue-origins-older-than-spacex-in-more-ways-than-one |archive-date=April 16, 2017}}</ref>
Since the founding, the company was quite secretive about its plans<ref name="msnbc20060624">{{Cite web |last=Alan Boyle |date=June 24, 2006 |title=Blue's Rocket Clues |url=http://cosmiclog.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2006/06/24/669.aspx |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411045902/http://cosmiclog.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2006/06/24/669.aspx |archive-date=April 11, 2008 |access-date=May 28, 2008 |publisher=msnbc |df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=nsj20131207/> and emerged from its "self-imposed silence" only after 2015.<ref name=sir20170414/>

The company was incorporated in 2000 and in 2003, Bezos began buying land in Texas, at which point interested parties{{who|date=October 2021}} followed up on the purchases. This was a topic of some interest in local politics, and Bezos' rapid aggregation of land under a variety of whimsically named [[Shell corporation|shell companies]] was called{{by whom|date=June 2020}} a "land grab".<ref name="wsj">{{Cite news |last=Mylene Mangalindan |date=November 10, 2006 |title=Buzz in West Texas is about Jeff Bezos space craft launch site |work=The Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB116312683235519444?mod=googlenews_wsj |url-status=live |access-date=May 28, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171224232011/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB116312683235519444?mod=googlenews_wsj |archive-date=December 24, 2017}}</ref>

[[Rob Meyerson]] joined Blue Origin in 2003 and served as the company's long-time president. Meyerson led the growth of the company from 10 to 1500 people before leaving in late 2018.<ref name=":1" />

As early as 2005, Bezos had discussed plans to create a vertical-takeoff and landing spaceship called [[New Shepard]]. Plans for New Shepard were initially kept quiet, but Blue Origin's website indicated Bezos' desire to, "lower the cost of spaceflight so that we humans can better continue exploring the Solar System."<ref>{{Cite news |title=Accidents Won't Stop Private Space Industry's Push to Final Frontier |language=en-US |magazine=WIRED |url=https://www.wired.com/2007/08/rocketeers/ |url-status=live |access-date=July 17, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180717212438/https://www.wired.com/2007/08/rocketeers/ |archive-date=July 17, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Michael Graczyk |date=March 15, 2005 |title=Blue Origin Spaceport Plans are Talk of Texas Town |work=space.com |url=http://www.space.com/missionlaunches/ap_bezos_spaceport_050315.html |url-status=dead |access-date=May 28, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724055135/http://www.space.com/missionlaunches/ap_bezos_spaceport_050315.html |archive-date=July 24, 2008}}</ref><ref name="msnbc20060624" /> By 2008, a publicized timetable for New Shepard indicated that Blue Origin intended to fly [[Uncrewed vehicle|uncrewed]] in 2011, and crewed in 2012.<ref name="fg200812">{{cite web |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/blogs/hyperbola/2008/12/whatever-happened-to-blue-orig.html |title= Whatever happened to Blue Origin? - Hyperbola|website=www.flightglobal.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217041134/http://www.flightglobal.com/blogs/hyperbola/2008/12/whatever-happened-to-blue-orig.html |archive-date=December 17, 2008}}</ref> In a 2011 interview, Bezos indicated that he founded Blue Origin to send customers into [[outer space|space]] by focusing on two objectives: to decrease the cost and to increase the safety of [[human spaceflight]].<ref name="wired20111113">{{Cite magazine |last=Levy |first=Stephen |date=November 13, 2011 |title=Jeff Bezos Owns the Web in More Ways Than You Think |url=https://www.wired.com/magazine/2011/11/ff_bezos/all/1 |url-status=live |magazine=Wired |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111210145216/http://www.wired.com/magazine/2011/11/ff_bezos/all/1 |archive-date=December 10, 2011 |access-date=December 9, 2011}}</ref> By late 2016, Blue Origin was projecting that if all New Shepard test flights operated as scheduled, they could begin flying passengers to space on the ''New Shepard'' in 2018.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Morris |first=David |date=October 15, 2016 |title=Blue Origin Will Take Tourists to Space by 2018 |url=http://fortune.com/2016/10/15/jeff-bezos-blue-origin-2/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161203164446/http://fortune.com/2016/10/15/jeff-bezos-blue-origin-2/ |archive-date=December 3, 2016 |access-date=December 6, 2016 |website=Fortune.com}}</ref>

In July 2013, the company employed approximately 250 people.<ref name="gw20160305" /> By May 2015, the company had grown to approximately 400 employees, with 350 of those working on engineering, manufacturing and business operations in the Kent location<ref name="st20150531">{{Cite news |date=May 31, 2015 |title=Local engineers aim high for cheaper spaceflight |work=The Seattle Times |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/business/boeing-aerospace/space-wa2/ |url-status=live |access-date=June 1, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150718142524/http://www.seattletimes.com/business/boeing-aerospace/space-wa2/ |archive-date=July 18, 2015}}</ref> and approximately 50 in Texas supporting the engine-test and suborbital test-flight facility.<ref name="st20150531" />
More rapid growth began in 2016. By April 2017, the company had more than 1000 employees.<ref name="sir20170414" /> In August 2018, the company was more than 1500 employees, more than double the number in early 2016, and stated that they expected that "to double again by the time New Glenn is flying."<ref name="reuters20180802">{{Cite news |last=Johnson |first=Eric M. |date=August 2, 2018 |title=Bezos throws cash, engineers at rocket program as space race accelerates |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-space-blueorigin/bezos-throws-cash-engineers-at-rocket-program-as-space-race-accelerates-idUSKBN1KO0HN |url-status=live |access-date=August 4, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180803213437/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-space-blueorigin/bezos-throws-cash-engineers-at-rocket-program-as-space-race-accelerates-idUSKBN1KO0HN |archive-date=August 3, 2018}}</ref>
But Blue had more than 2000 employees by April 2019 – two years before New Glenn's anticipated first flight – with plans to have more than 2600 by the end of 2019.<!-- a walk through the various Blue facilities around the US was also in the video, prior to 13 minutes --><ref name="blue_NS-1120190502">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T84qFp4_3ns Replay of NS-11 Webcast] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190505024237/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T84qFp4_3ns |date=May 5, 2019 }}, at 13:03, Blue Origin, via YouTube, May 2, 2019, accessed May 5, 2019.</ref>

By July 2014, Bezos had invested over {{usd|500 million}} of his own money into Blue Origin.<ref name="sn20140718">{{Cite news |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=July 18, 2014 |title=Bezos Investment in Blue Origin Exceeds $500 Million |publisher=Space News |url=http://www.spacenews.com/article/civil-space/41299bezos-investment-in-blue-origin-exceeds-500-million |archive-url=https://archive.today/20140719021511/http://www.spacenews.com/article/civil-space/41299bezos-investment-in-blue-origin-exceeds-500-million |url-status=dead |archive-date=July 19, 2014 |access-date=July 20, 2014}}</ref>
As of 2016, Blue Origin was spending {{USD|1 billion}} a year, funded by Jeff Bezos' sales of Amazon stock.<ref name="nyt20170405" /> In both 2017, and again in 2018, Bezos made public statements that he intends to fund Blue Origin with {{USD|1 billion}} per year from sales of his equity in Amazon.<ref name="bi20180428">[http://www.businessinsider.com/jeff-bezos-interview-axel-springer-ceo-amazon-trump-blue-origin-family-regulation-washington-post-2018-4 Jeff Bezos reveals what it's like to build an empire and become the richest man in the world – and why he's willing to spend $1 billion a year to fund the most important mission of his life] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180430233857/http://www.businessinsider.com/jeff-bezos-interview-axel-springer-ceo-amazon-trump-blue-origin-family-regulation-washington-post-2018-4 |date=April 30, 2018 }}, Business Insider, April 28, 2018, accessed May 1, 2018.</ref>

The first developmental test flight of the ''New Shepard'' occurred on April 29, 2015.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Watch the incredible first test flight of Jeff Bezos's mysterious new rocket |work=Business Insider |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/blue-origin-new-shepard-first-test-flight-2015-4 |url-status=live |access-date=July 17, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180717183851/http://www.businessinsider.com/blue-origin-new-shepard-first-test-flight-2015-4 |archive-date=July 17, 2018}}</ref> The uncrewed vehicle flew to its planned test altitude of more than {{Cvt|93.5|km|ft}} and achieved a top speed of [[Mach number|Mach]] 3.<ref name="Senior Staff Writer">{{Cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |title=Senior Staff Writer |url=http://spacenews.com/blue-origins-new-shepard-vehicle-makes-first-test-flight/ |access-date=May 5, 2015 |website=Space News|date=April 30, 2015 }}</ref> In July 2015, [[NanoRacks]], a provider of services such as payload design and development, safety approvals, and integration, announced a partnership with Blue Origin to provide standardized payload accommodations for experiments flying on Blue Origin's [[Blue Origin New Shepard|''New Shepard'']] suborbital vehicle.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=July 16, 2015 |title=NanoRacks And Blue Origin Team To Fly Suborbital Research Payloads |url=http://spacenews.com/nanoracks-and-blue-origin-team-to-fly-suborbital-research-payloads/ |website=SpaceNews}}</ref>

In September 2014, the company and [[United Launch Alliance]] (ULA) entered into a partnership whereby Blue Origin would produce a large rocket engine – the [[BE-4]] – for the [[Vulcan (rocket)|Vulcan]], the successor to the {{convert|10000|-|19,000|kg|lb|adj=mid|-class}} [[Atlas V]] which has launched US national security payloads since the early 2000s, and was then scheduled to exit service in the late 2010s.<ref name="sir20170414" /> The 2014 announcement added that Blue Origin had been working on the engine for three years prior to the public announcement, and that the first flight on the new rocket could occur as early as 2019.<ref name="wp201409">{{Cite news |last=Achenbach |first=Joel |date=September 17, 2014 |title=Jeff Bezos's Blue Origin to supply engines for national security space launches |newspaper=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/jeff-bezos-and-blue-origin-to-supply-engines-for-national-security-space-launches/2014/09/17/59f46eb2-3e7b-11e4-9587-5dafd96295f0_story.html |url-status=live |access-date=September 27, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140925075923/http://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/jeff-bezos-and-blue-origin-to-supply-engines-for-national-security-space-launches/2014/09/17/59f46eb2-3e7b-11e4-9587-5dafd96295f0_story.html |archive-date=September 25, 2014}}</ref> In actuality, Atlas V is still flying in 2020.
By April 2017, [[new product development|development]] and test of the {{convert|550000|lbf|kN|lk=on|abbr=on|order=flip|adj=on}} BE-4 were progressing well and Blue Origin was expected to be selected for the ULA [[Vulcan launch vehicle|Vulcan]] rocket.<ref name="sir20170414" /> In April 2015, Blue Origin announced that it had completed [[acceptance testing]] of the [[BE-3]] rocket engine that would power the [[Blue Origin New Shepard|New Shepard]] [[space capsule]] to be used for Blue Origin [[suborbital spaceflight|suborbital]] flights.<ref name="tsr20150413">{{Cite news |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=April 13, 2015 |title=Blue Origin's suborbital plans are finally ready for flight |url=http://www.thespacereview.com/article/2729/1 |url-status=live |access-date=April 18, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418190451/http://www.thespacereview.com/article/2729/1 |archive-date=April 18, 2015 |quote=''We've recently completed acceptance testing, meaning we've accepted the engine for suborbital flight on our New Shepard vehicle, [the end of a] very, very long development program [of] 450 test firings of the engine and a cumulative run time of more than {{cvt|500|min|h|disp=sqbr|abbr=off}}. The completion of those tests sets the stage for Blue Origin to begin test flights of the vehicle later this year at its facility in West Texas [where they] expect a series of flight tests with this vehicle ... flying in autonomous mode ... We expect a series of dozens of flights over the extent of the test program [taking] a couple of years to complete.''}}</ref>

On November 23, 2015, Blue Origin launched the New Shepard rocket to space for a second time<ref>{{Cite news |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |title=Journalist |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/25/science/space/blue-origins-rocket-launches-and-lands.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125040343/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/25/science/space/blue-origins-rocket-launches-and-lands.html |archive-date=November 25, 2015 |access-date=November 24, 2015 |website=The New York Times|date=November 24, 2015 }}</ref> to an altitude of {{Cvt|329839|ft|km|2|order=flip}}, and vertically landed the rocket booster less than {{convert|5|ft|order=flip|sp=us}} from the center of the pad. The capsule descended to the ground under parachutes 11 minutes after blasting off and landed safely. This was the first time a suborbital booster had flown to space and returned to Earth.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Cofeld |first=Calla |title=Staff Writer |url=http://www.space.com/31214-spaceflight-golden-age-jeff-bezos.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126134751/http://www.space.com/31214-spaceflight-golden-age-jeff-bezos.html |archive-date=November 26, 2015 |access-date=November 25, 2015 |website=Space.com |date=November 25, 2015 |publisher=Space.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Blue Origin Launches Bezos's Space Dreams and Lands a Rocket |language=en |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/25/science/space/blue-origins-rocket-launches-and-lands.html |url-status=live |access-date=July 17, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125040343/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/25/science/space/blue-origins-rocket-launches-and-lands.html |archive-date=November 25, 2015}}</ref> This flight validated the vehicle architecture and design. The ring fin shifted the center of pressure aft to help control reentry and descent; eight large drag brakes deployed and reduced the vehicle's terminal speed to {{cvt|387|mph||order=flip}}; hydraulically actuated fins steered the vehicle through {{convert|119|mph||abbr=on|order=flip}} high-altitude crosswinds to a location precisely aligned with and {{cvt|5,000|ft||order=flip}} above the landing pad; then the highly throttleable BE-3 engine re-ignited to slow the booster as the landing gear deployed, and the vehicle descended the last {{cvt|100|feet||order=flip}} at {{cvt|4.4|mph||order=flip}} to touchdown on the pad.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Bezos|first=Jeff|title=Historic Rocket Landing|url=https://www.blueorigin.com/news/blog/historic-rocket-landing|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151210181619/https://www.blueorigin.com/news/blog/historic-rocket-landing|archive-date=December 10, 2015|access-date=November 23, 2015|website=www.blueorigin.com|publisher=Blue Origin}}</ref>
On January 22, 2016, Blue Origin re-flew the same New Shepard booster that launched and landed vertically in November 2015, demonstrating reuse. This time, New Shepard reached an apogee of {{Cvt|333,582|ft|km|1|order=flip}} before both capsule and booster returned to Earth for recovery and reuse.  In April 2016, the same New Shepard booster again flew, now for a third time, reaching {{Cvt|339,178|ft|km|1|order=flip}}, before again returning and landing successfully.<ref name="techcrunch20160402" />

In September 2015, Blue Origin announced details of an unnamed planned [[orbital spaceflight|orbital]] launch vehicle, indicating that the first stage would be powered by its [[BE-4]] rocket engine currently under development, while the second stage would be powered by its recently completed [[BE-3]] rocket engine. In addition, Blue Origin announced that it would both manufacture and launch the new rocket from the [[Space Coast|Florida Space Coast]].  No payload or gross launch weight was given. Bezos noted in interviews that this new launch vehicle would not [[Space launch market competition|compete]] for US government [[National security of the United States|national security]] missions, leaving that market to [[United Launch Alliance]] and [[SpaceX]].<ref name="sn20150915">{{Cite news |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=September 15, 2015 |title=Bezos Not Concerned About Competition, Possible ULA Sale |work=Space News |url=http://spacenews.com/bezos-not-concerned-about-competition-possible-ula-sale/ |access-date=September 16, 2015}}</ref> Science-fiction author [[Neal Stephenson]] worked part-time at Blue Origin into late 2006<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.mac.com/nealstephenson/Neal_Stephensons_Site/Blue_Origin_LLC.html |title= Blue Origin LLC|website=web.mac.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813181219/http://web.mac.com/nealstephenson/Neal_Stephensons_Site/Blue_Origin_LLC.html |archive-date=August 13, 2009}}</ref> and credited the company's employees for ideas and discussions leading to his 2015 novel, [[Seveneves]].

In March 2016, Blue Origin invited journalists to see the inside of its [[Kent, Washington]] headquarters and manufacturing facility for the first time. The company was planning for substantial growth in 2016 as it planned to build more crew capsules and propulsion modules for the New Shepard program and ramp up BE-4 engine builds to support full-scale development testing.  Blue indicated that employment was expected to grow to 1,000 in 2016 from 600 in February 2016.<ref name="sn20160308">{{Cite news |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=March 8, 2016 |title=Blue Origin plans growth spurt this year |work=[[SpaceNews]] |url=http://spacenews.com/blue-origin-plans-growth-spurt-this-year/ |access-date=March 13, 2016}}</ref>
Bezos also articulated a long-term vision for humans in space, seeing the potential to move much heavy industry completely off-Earth, "leaving our planet zoned strictly for 'residential and light industrial' use with an end state hundreds of years out "where millions of people would be living and working in space."<ref name="gw20160305">{{Cite news |last=Boyle |first=Alan |date=March 5, 2016 |title=Jeff Bezos lifts curtain on Blue Origin rocket factory, lays out grand plan for space travel that spans hundreds of years |work=[[GeekWire]] |url=http://www.geekwire.com/2016/jeff-bezos-lifts-curtain-blue-origin-rocket-factory-vision-space/ |url-status=live |access-date=March 9, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309191618/http://www.geekwire.com/2016/jeff-bezos-lifts-curtain-blue-origin-rocket-factory-vision-space/ |archive-date=March 9, 2016}}</ref> In March 2016, test flights carrying human occupants were said by the company to be possible as early as 2017, potentially with commercial service in 2018.<ref name="Fedde">{{Cite web |last=Fedde |first=Corey |date=March 9, 2016 |title=How Blue Origin plans to soon send people into space, safely |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Science/2016/0309/How-Blue-Origin-plans-to-soon-send-people-into-space-safely |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310062341/http://www.csmonitor.com/Science/2016/0309/How-Blue-Origin-plans-to-soon-send-people-into-space-safely |archive-date=March 10, 2016 |access-date=March 10, 2016 |website=The Christian Science Monitor}}</ref> The newly disclosed orbital rocket – which would subsequently be named New Glenn – was planned to fly its initial flight in 2020.<ref name=gw20160305/>

Also in March 2016, Bezos discussed his plans to offer [[space tourism]] services to space.  Pointing out the "entertainment" aspect of the early "[[Barnstorming|barnstormers]]" in really advancing aviation in the early days when such rides "were a big fraction of airplane flights in those early days," he sees space tourism playing a similar role:  advancing "space travel and rocket launches, through tourism and entertainment."<ref name=ft20160312/>
On the other hand, {{as of|2016|lc=y}} there were no current plans to pursue the niche market of [[US military]] launches; Bezos said he is unsure where Blue Origin would add any value in that market.<ref name="ft20160312">{{Cite news |last=Price |first=Wayne T. |date=March 12, 2016 |title=Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin could change the face of space travel |work=[[Florida Today]] |url=http://www.floridatoday.com/story/news/local/2016/03/12/jeff-bezos-blue-origin-amazon-space-exploration-brevard-county-florida/81649214/ |url-status=live |access-date=March 13, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180106065214/http://www.floridatoday.com/story/news/local/2016/03/12/jeff-bezos-blue-origin-amazon-space-exploration-brevard-county-florida/81649214/ |archive-date=January 6, 2018}}</ref> This would later change.<ref name=ars20210301/>

In September 2016, Blue announced that its orbital rocket would be named New Glenn in honor of the first American astronaut to orbit the Earth, [[John Glenn]], and that the {{convert|23|ft|m|0|order=flip|sp=us|adj=mid|-diameter}} first stage will be powered by seven Blue Origin [[BE-4]] engines. The first stage is reusable and will [[VTVL|land vertically]], just like the New Shepard [[sub-orbital spaceflight|suborbital]] launch vehicle that preceded it.<ref name="nsf20160912" />

In March 2017, Bezos announced that Blue Origin had acquired its first paying launch customer for orbital satellite launches. [[Eutelsat]] was expected to start launching TV satellites in 2022 on Blue Origin's [[New Glenn]] orbital launch vehicle.<ref name="NYT-2017-03-07">{{Cite news |last=Cecilia King |date=March 7, 2017 |title=Blue Origin, Jeff Bezos's Moon Shot, Gets First Paying Customer |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/07/technology/blue-origin-jeff-bezoss-moon-shot-gets-first-paying-customer.html |url-status=live |access-date=May 5, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170502120139/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/07/technology/blue-origin-jeff-bezoss-moon-shot-gets-first-paying-customer.html |archive-date=May 2, 2017}}</ref> A day after announcing Eutelsat, Blue Origin introduced [[OneWeb]] as its second customer.<ref>{{Cite news |date=March 8, 2017 |title=Jeff Bezos adds OneWeb satellite venture to Blue Origin's New Glenn launch manifest |language=en-US |work=GeekWire |url=https://www.geekwire.com/2017/jeff-bezos-oneweb-satellite-blue-origin-new-glenn/ |url-status=live |access-date=January 25, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180126013954/https://www.geekwire.com/2017/jeff-bezos-oneweb-satellite-blue-origin-new-glenn/ |archive-date=January 26, 2018}}</ref> In September 2017, Blue Origin closed a deal for New Glenn with its first Asian customer, [[Mu Space]].<ref>{{Cite news |date=September 26, 2017 |title=The Rocket Company of Jeff Bezos Has Its First Asian Customer  |language=en-US |work=Finance.co.uk  |url=https://news.finance.co.uk/rocket-company-jeff-bezos-first-asian-customer/ |access-date=January 25, 2018}}</ref> The company, based in Thailand, plans to provide satellite-based broadband services and space travel in Asia-Pacific.<ref>{{Cite news |date=September 26, 2017 |title=Blue Origin announces satellite launch deal with Thai telecom startup Mu Space |language=en-US |work=GeekWire |url=https://www.geekwire.com/2017/blue-origin-strikes-satellite-launch-deal-thai-telecon-startup-mu-space/ |url-status=live |access-date=January 25, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180125134519/https://www.geekwire.com/2017/blue-origin-strikes-satellite-launch-deal-thai-telecon-startup-mu-space/ |archive-date=January 25, 2018}}</ref>

In December 2017, Blue Origin launched a test experiment on New Shepard with a technology that could one day treat chest trauma in a space environment.<ref>{{Cite web |title=NASA Funds Flight for Space Medical Technology on Blue Origin |url=http://link.galegroup.com/apps/doc/A519291562/ITOF?u=mcc_pv&sid=ITOF&xid=4d2aa1d4 |access-date=February 5, 2018 |website=link.galegroup.com |language=en}}</ref>

In June 2018, Blue Origin indicated that while it continued to plan to fly initial internal passengers later in 2018, it would not be selling commercial tickets for New Shepard until 2019.<ref name="sn20180621">{{Cite news |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=June 21, 2018 |title=Blue Origin plans to start selling suborbital spaceflight tickets next year |work=[[SpaceNews]] |url=https://spacenews.com/blue-origin-plans-to-start-selling-suborbital-spaceflight-tickets-next-year/ |access-date=June 25, 2018}}</ref>

In May 2019 Blue Origin announced the ''Blue Moon'' [[Lunar lander|lander]] design concept,<ref name="cnbc20190509">{{Cite web |last=Sheetz |first=Michael |date=May 9, 2019 |title=Jeff Bezos unveils Blue Origin's Blue Moon lunar lander for astronauts |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/09/jeff-bezos-unveils-blue-moon-lunar-lander.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190510122842/https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/09/jeff-bezos-unveils-blue-moon-lunar-lander.html |archive-date=May 10, 2019 |access-date=May 10, 2019 |website=[[CNBC]]}}</ref>
expected to fly on the New Glenn launch vehicle and be ready to make a soft landing on the Moon as early as 2024. They also announced the [[#BE-7|BE-7]] engine.  The lander, part of Blue Origin's entry in NASA's [[Human Landing System]] competition, is slated to be able to be built in two versions, and transport {{Convert|3.6|–|6.5|tonnes|lb|abbr=on}}.<ref name="sfn20190509">{{Cite news |last=Clark |first=Stephen |date=May 9, 2019 |title=Jeff Bezos unveils 'Blue Moon' lander |work=Spaceflight Now |url=https://spaceflightnow.com/2019/05/09/blue-origin-announcement/ |url-status=live |access-date=May 11, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190510041940/https://spaceflightnow.com/2019/05/09/blue-origin-announcement/ |archive-date=May 10, 2019}}</ref>

Despite publicly announced plans to fly passengers on New Shepard in 2018 and begin commercial flights in 2019,<ref name=sn20180621/> as of March 2021, Blue Origin had yet to fly commercial passengers (or indeed, any passengers) on the suborbital rocket.<ref name="ars20210301">{{Cite news |last=Berger |first=Eric |date=March 1, 2021 |title=Blue Origin's massive New Glenn rocket is delayed for years. What went wrong? |work=[[Ars Technica]] |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/03/so-what-really-happened-with-blue-origins-new-glenn-rocket/ |accessdate=March 3, 2021}}</ref> On December 11, 2019, the company completed its twelfth test flight of the rocket.<ref>{{Cite web |author=Jackie Wattles |date=December 11, 2019 |title=Jeff Bezos's Blue Origin launches 12th test flight of space tourism rocket |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/12/11/tech/blue-origin-jeff-bezos-new-shepard-test-flight-scn/index.html |access-date=June 14, 2021 |website=CNN |language=en}}</ref>

In early 2021, Blue announced a revised schedule estimate for the first launch of New Glenn.<ref name=ars20210301/> While initially planned to fly as early as 2020<ref name=gw20160305/> the company announced in March 2021 that New Glenn "would not launch until the fourth quarter of 2022, at the earliest."<ref name=ars20210301/>

In June 2021, Blue Origin auctioned off a seat on the company's debut [[Commercial astronaut|private astronaut mission]] for $28 million; however, the winner of the auction did not take part in the flight due to a scheduling conflict. The winner remained initially anonymous but later revealed himself as [[Justin Sun]].<ref name="spacenews.com">{{Cite web|url=https://spacenews.com/crypto-entrepreneur-to-go-to-space-on-new-shepard/|title=Crypto entrepreneur to go to space on New Shepard|date=December 23, 2021|website=SpaceNews}}</ref> [[Blue Origin NS-16|The launch]] took place on July 20, 2021, with Oliver Daemen flying in the seat that Mr. Sun had won in the auction.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin auctions off seat on first human spaceflight for $28M |url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2021/06/12/jeff-bezos-blue-origin-auctions-off-seat-on-first-human-spaceflight-for-28m/ |access-date=June 14, 2021 |website=TechCrunch |language=en-US}}</ref>

In August 2021, Blue Origin began a lawsuit against the United States federal government over its failed bid on the Human Landing System contract, which included the Blue Moon lander. Blue Origin claims NASA unlawfully and improperly evaluated the proposals. The US [[Government Accountability Office]] (GAO) investigated the allegations and sided with NASA. Blue Origin's lawsuit is causing delays to the [[Artemis program]] and NASA's planned moon landing.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin sues U.S. government over SpaceX lunar lander contract |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/aerospace-defense/blue-origin-sues-us-government-over-spacex-lunar-lander-contract-2021-08-16/ |website=Reuters |date=August 16, 2021 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=NASA Wants To Return To The Moon By 2024, But The Spacesuits Won't Be Ready|url=https://www.npr.org/2021/08/21/1029750027/nasa-moon-spacesuits-astronauts-return-2024-problems|access-date=2021-08-22|newspaper=NPR|date=August 21, 2021|language=en|last1=Doubek|first1=James}}</ref>

In October 2021, [[William Shatner]] (age 90), the actor who played [[Captain Kirk]] on the [[Original Star Trek series]], boarded a Blue Origin sub-orbital capsule and [[Blue Origin NS-18|successfully flew to space]] becoming the oldest person to fly to space.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/391021|title = Captain Kirk's space voyage with Blue Origin lands successfully}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abc7chicago.com/william-shatner-captain-kirk-blue-origin-jeff-bezos/11120357/|title = 'Star Trek' actor William Shatner blasts off into space in Blue Origin launch|date = October 13, 2021}}</ref>

The [[Blue Origin NS-19|third crewed mission]] of New Shepard launched 11 December 2021. The [[Blue Origin NS-20|fourth crewed mission]] of New Shepard launched 31 March 2022. On 4 June 2022, New Shepard completed its [[Blue Origin NS-21|fifth crewed mission]] launch after the delayed voyage previous month.<ref name="Johnson">{{Cite news |last=Johnson |first=Katanga |date=2022-06-05 |title=Bezos' Blue Origin completes fifth crewed flight launch |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/aerospace-defense/bezos-blue-origin-completes-fifth-crewed-flight-launch-2022-06-04/ |access-date=2022-06-05}}</ref> The [[Blue Origin NS-22|sixth crewed flight]] took place 4 August 2022.

== Vehicles and Projects ==
===Test Vehicles===
==== ''Charon'' ====
[[File:Blue Origin Charon Test Vehicle - Flickr - brewbooks.jpg|thumb|''Charon'' on display at the [[Museum of Flight]] in Seattle, Washington.]]
Blue Origin's first flight test vehicle, called ''[[Charon (moon)|Charon]]'' after [[Pluto]]'s moon,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Boyle |first=Alan |title=Amazon.com billionaire's 5-ton flying jetpack lands in Seattle museum |url=http://cosmiclog.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/05/24/11862569-amazoncom-billionaires-5-ton-flying-jetpack-lands-in-seattle-museum?lite |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170203081705/http://cosmiclog.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/05/24/11862569-amazoncom-billionaires-5-ton-flying-jetpack-lands-in-seattle-museum?lite |archive-date=February 3, 2017 |access-date=February 2, 2017 |website=NBC News}}</ref> was powered by four vertically mounted [[Armstrong Siddeley Viper|Rolls-Royce Viper Mk. 301]] jet engines rather than rockets. The low-altitude vehicle was developed to test autonomous guidance and control technologies, and the processes that the company would use to develop its later rockets. ''Charon'' made its only test flight at Moses Lake, Washington on March 5, 2005. It flew to an altitude of {{Cvt|316|ft||order=flip}} before returning for a controlled landing near the liftoff point.<ref name="Blue Origin Charon Test Vehicle">{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin Charon Test Vehicle |url=http://www.museumofflight.org/aircraft/charon-test-vehicle |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130324015036/http://www.museumofflight.org/aircraft/charon-test-vehicle |archive-date=March 24, 2013 |access-date=March 4, 2013 |publisher=The Museum of Flight}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin's Original Charon Flying Vehicle Goes on Display at The Museum of Flight |url=http://www.museumofflight.org/news/blue-origins-original-charon-flying-vehicle-goes-display-museum-flight |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130328144750/http://www.museumofflight.org/news/blue-origins-original-charon-flying-vehicle-goes-display-museum-flight |archive-date=March 28, 2013 |access-date=March 4, 2013 |publisher=The Museum of Flight |df=mdy-all}}</ref>

As of 2016, Charon is on display at the [[Museum of Flight]] in Seattle, Washington.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin Charon Test Vehicle |url=http://www.museumofflight.org/aircraft/charon-test-vehicle |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130324015036/http://www.museumofflight.org/aircraft/charon-test-vehicle |archive-date=March 24, 2013 |access-date=August 6, 2016 |publisher=Museum of Flight}}</ref>

==== Goddard ====
The next test vehicle, named ''[[Blue Origin Goddard|Goddard]]'' (also known as PM1), first flew on November 13, 2006. The flight was successful. A test flight for December 2 never launched.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Alan Boyle |date=November 28, 2006 |title=Blue Origin Rocket Report |url=http://cosmiclog.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2006/11/28/16017.aspx |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080415154004/http://cosmiclog.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2006/11/28/16017.aspx |archive-date=April 15, 2008 |access-date=May 28, 2008 |publisher=cosmiclog.msnbc.msn.com |df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Alan Boyle |date=December 2, 2006 |title=Blue Alert For Blastoff |url=http://cosmiclog.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2006/12/02/16849.aspx |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080507171757/http://cosmiclog.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2006/12/02/16849.aspx |archive-date=May 7, 2008 |access-date=May 28, 2008 |publisher=cosmiclog.msnbc.msn.com |df=mdy-all}}</ref> According to [[Federal Aviation Administration]] records, two further flights were performed by Goddard.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Launches |url=https://www.faa.gov/data_research/commercial_space_data/launches/?type=Permitted |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190421174346/https://www.faa.gov/data_research/commercial_space_data/launches/?type=Permitted |archive-date=April 21, 2019 |access-date=April 4, 2019 |website=www.faa.gov |language=en-us}}</ref>

====PM2====

Another early suborbital test vehicle, PM2, had two flight tests in 2011 in west Texas. The vehicle designation may be short for "Propulsion Module".<ref name="nsj20110902">{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin has a bad day (and so do some of the media) |url=http://www.newspacejournal.com/2011/09/02/blue-origin-has-a-bad-day-and-so-do-some-of-the-media/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120126001453/http://www.newspacejournal.com/2011/09/02/blue-origin-has-a-bad-day-and-so-do-some-of-the-media/ |archive-date=January 26, 2012 |access-date=September 3, 2011}}</ref>

The first flight was a short hop (low altitude, VTVL takeoff and landing mission) flown on 6 May 2011. The second flight, August 24 2011, failed when ground personnel lost contact and control of the vehicle. Blue Origin released its analysis of the failure nine days later.  As the vehicle reached a speed of [[Mach number|Mach]] 1.2 and {{convert|14|km|ft|abbr=on}} altitude, a "flight instability drove an [[angle of attack]] that triggered [the] [[Range Safety and Telemetry System|range safety system]] to terminate thrust on the vehicle".<ref name="PM2">{{cite news|title=Blue Origin Acknowledges Test Flight Failure|url=https://spacenews.com/blue-origin-acknowledges-test-flight-failure/|date=September 12, 2011|access-date=November 3, 2022|publisher=Space News}}</ref>

=== New Shepard ===
{{Further|New Shepard}}{{Cleanup section|reason=[[WP:PROSELINE]].|date=July 2021}}[[File:Blue Origin New Shepard Launch april 2015.jpg|thumb|[[New Shepard]] launch on April 29, 2015]]

Blue Origin's New Shepard [[suborbital]] [[spaceflight]] system is composed of two vehicles: a crew capsule accommodating three or more astronauts launched by a [[Blue Origin propulsion module|rocket booster]]. The two vehicles lift off together and are designed to separate during flight. After separation, the booster is designed to return to Earth to perform a [[VTVL|vertical landing]] while the crew capsule follows a separate trajectory, returning under parachutes for a land touchdown. Both vehicles are intended for recovery and re-use.<ref name="Blue Origin – About Blue">{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin – About Blue |url=http://www.blueorigin.com/about/about.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130325181227/http://www.blueorigin.com/about/about.html |archive-date=March 25, 2013 |access-date=April 5, 2013}}</ref> ''New Shepard'' is controlled entirely by on-board computers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.faa.gov/about/office_org/headquarters_offices/ast/media/20060829_Blue_Origin_EA_FONSI_signed.pdf |title= Department of Transportation Federal Aviation Administration Finding of No Significant Impact|website=www.faa.gov |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090515030315/http://www.faa.gov/about/office_org/headquarters_offices/ast/media/20060829_Blue_Origin_EA_FONSI_signed.pdf |archive-date=May 15, 2009}}</ref> In addition to flying astronauts, New Shepard is intended to provide frequent opportunities for researchers to fly experiments into suborbital space.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin – Research |url=http://www.blueorigin.com/research/research.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130413023319/http://www.blueorigin.com/research/research.html |archive-date=April 13, 2013 |access-date=April 5, 2013}}</ref>

[[File:Blue Origin Test Landing with Parachutes April 2015.jpg|thumb|New Shepard landing with parachutes on April 29, 2015]]

In October 2012, Blue Origin conducted a successful New Shepard pad escape test at its West Texas launch site, firing its pusher escape motor and launching a full-scale crew capsule from a launch vehicle simulator. The crew capsule traveled to an altitude of {{convert|2307|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip}} under active thrust vector control before descending safely by parachute to a [[Soft landing (rocketry)|soft landing]] {{convert|1630|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip}} downrange.<ref name="bo20121022">{{Cite web |date=October 22, 2012 |title=Blue Origin Conducts Successful Pad Escape Test |url=http://www.blueorigin.com/media/press_release/blue-origin-conducts-successful-pad-escape-test |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131215050523/http://www.blueorigin.com/media/press_release/blue-origin-conducts-successful-pad-escape-test |archive-date=December 15, 2013 |access-date=December 5, 2013 |publisher=Blue Origin}}</ref>

In April 2015, Blue Origin announced its intent to begin [[autonomous robot|autonomous]] [[flight testing|test flights]] of New Shepard in 2015 as frequently as monthly. Blue Origin expected "a series of dozens of flights over the extent of the test program [taking] a couple of years to complete".<ref name=tsr20150413/>

New Shepard made its first test flight on April 29, 2015. The uncrewed vehicle flew to its planned test altitude of more than {{convert|93.5|km|ft|abbr=on}} and achieved a top speed of [[Mach number|Mach]] 3.<ref name="Senior Staff Writer" /> The crew capsule separated from the booster before returning to Earth and landing under parachutes.  The booster experienced a hydraulic failure that prevented it from landing and was destroyed on impact.<ref name="bo20150430">{{Cite news |title=Bezos' Blue Origin completes first test flight of 'New Shepard' spacecraft |work=SpaceFlightNow |publisher=SpaceFlightNow |url=https://spaceflightnow.com/2015/04/30/bezos-blue-origin-completes-first-test-flight-of-new-shepard-spacecraft/ |url-status=live |access-date=April 7, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190407231617/https://spaceflightnow.com/2015/04/30/bezos-blue-origin-completes-first-test-flight-of-new-shepard-spacecraft/ |archive-date=April 7, 2019}}</ref>

On November 23, 2015, New Shepard made its second test flight, reaching {{cvt|100.5|km|ft}} altitude with a successful [[VTVL|vertical landing]] and recovery of the booster, the first time a booster stage that had been to [[outer space|space]] had ever [[Soft landing (rocketry)|done so]].<ref name="First">{{Cite news |date=November 24, 2015 |title=Blue Origin Makes Historic Rocket Landing |work=Blue Origin |url=https://www.blueorigin.com/news/news/blue-origin-makes-historic-rocket-landing |url-status=dead |access-date=November 24, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125051400/https://www.blueorigin.com/news/news/blue-origin-makes-historic-rocket-landing |archive-date=November 25, 2015}}</ref><ref name="bbc">{{Cite news |last=Amos |first=Jonathan |date=November 24, 2015 |title=New Shepard: Bezos claims success on second spaceship flight |work=[[BBC News]] |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-34909713 |url-status=live |access-date=November 26, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180713204040/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-34909713 |archive-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref> The crew capsule was also successfully recovered via parachute return, as Blue had done before.<ref name=bbc/>

On January 22, 2016, Blue Origin re-flew the same New Shepard booster that launched and landed vertically in November 2015, demonstrating reuse. This time, New Shepard reached an apogee of {{Cvt|333,582|ft|km|1|order=flip}} before both capsule and booster again successfully returned to Earth with a soft landing for recovery and reuse.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Dillow |first=Clay |title=Reporter |url=http://fortune.com/2016/01/25/blue-origin-makes-history-by-landing-reusable-rocket-a-second-time/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128161819/http://fortune.com/2016/01/25/blue-origin-makes-history-by-landing-reusable-rocket-a-second-time/ |archive-date=January 28, 2016 |access-date=January 22, 2016 |website=Fortune.com |publisher=Fortune.com}}</ref>

Additional flights of New Shepard propulsion module 2 (NS2) were flown on April 2, 2016, reaching {{Cvt|339,178|ft|km|1|order=flip}},<ref>{{Cite web |last=Calandrelli |first=Emily |title=Blue Origin releases video from third launch and landing of New Shepard |url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/04/02/blue-origin-launches-and-lands-the-same-rocket-for-a-third-time/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403042600/http://techcrunch.com/2016/04/02/blue-origin-launches-and-lands-the-same-rocket-for-a-third-time/ |archive-date=April 3, 2016 |access-date=April 4, 2016 |website=TechCrunch.com}}</ref> and on June 19, 2016, for a fourth time, again reaching over {{Cvt|330000|ft|km|1|order=flip}}, before again returning and landing successfully.<ref name="verge20160619">{{Cite web |last=Grush |first=Loren |date=June 19, 2016 |title=Blue Origin safely launches and lands the New Shepard rocket for a fourth time |url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/6/19/11972450/blue-origin-new-shepard-fourth-test-flight-success |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730071430/https://www.theverge.com/2016/6/19/11972450/blue-origin-new-shepard-fourth-test-flight-success |archive-date=July 30, 2017 |access-date=June 19, 2016}}</ref> A fifth and final test flight of NS2 took place in October 2016 before NS2 was retired.<ref>{{cite web|last=Foust|first=Jeff|url=http://spacenews.com/blue-origin-successfully-tests-new-shepard-abort-system/|title=Blue Origin successfully tests New Shepard abort system|date=5 October 2016|work=[[SpaceNews]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Foust|first=Jeff|url=http://spacenews.com/blue-origin-plans-next-new-shepard-test-for-october/|title=Blue Origin plans next New Shepard test for October|work=[[SpaceNews]]|date=8 September 2016}}</ref>

The first flight of the third booster took place in December 2017.<ref>{{cite web |last=Bennett |first=Jay |date=December 13, 2017 |title=Blue Origin Launches New Crew Capsule on Third New Shepard Rocket |url=https://www.popularmechanics.com/space/rockets/a14425109/blue-origin-launches-new-crew-capsule-on-third-new-shepard-rocket/ |work=[[Popular Mechanics]]}}</ref>

The seventh test launch of [[New Shepard]] NS3 on October 13, 2020, successfully reached a maximum altitude of 105 km (346,000 ft).<ref>{{Cite news |date=October 14, 2020 |title=New Shepard: Jeff Bezos' rocket tests Nasa Moon landing tech |language=en-GB |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-54534012 |access-date=October 18, 2020}}</ref> On January 14, 2021, New Shepard successfully performed the first test flight of the New Shepard 4 (NS4), the fourth propulsion module to be built. It reached a maximum altitude of almost 107 km (350,827 ft).<ref>{{Cite news |date=January 15, 2021 |title=Blue Origin's 1st upgraded New Shepard spacecraft for astronauts aces launch (and landing) |language=en-GB |work=Space.com |url=https://www.space.com/blue-origin-new-shepard-ns-14-launch-landing-success |access-date=January 19, 2021}}</ref> On April 14, 2021, New Shepard successfully performed a landing with the reused rocket from the last flight.<ref>{{Cite web |date=April 14, 2021 |title=Blue Origin succeeds in 15th New Shepard flight, critical test before carrying humans |url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2021/04/blue-origin-new-shepard-15/ |website=NASA Spaceflight |accessdate=June 13, 2021}}</ref>

On July 20, 2021, New Shepard carried its first four passengers to suborbital space.<ref>{{cite web |last=Alamalhodaei |first=Aria |date=July 20, 2021 |title=Blue Origin's New Shepard carries Jeff Bezos and three crew members to space and back |url=https://techcrunch.com/2021/07/20/blue-origins-new-shepard-carries-jeff-bezos-and-three-crew-members-to-space-and-back/ |work=[[TechCrunch]]}}</ref> The passengers were [[Jeff Bezos]], his brother [[Mark Bezos]], [[Wally Funk]], and [[Oliver Daemen]], after the unnamed auction winner (later revealed to have been [[Justin Sun]]<ref name="spacenews.com"/>) dropped out due to a scheduling conflict. The second and third crewed missions of New Shepard took place in October and December 2021, respectively. Fourth crewed flight happened in March 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin's 20th Mission to Space |url=https://www.blueorigin.com/news/new-shepard-ns-20-mission-announcement |access-date=2022-06-05 |website=Blue Origin |language=en-US}}</ref> On 4 June 2022, New Shepard completed its [[Blue Origin NS-21|fifth crewed mission launch]] after the delayed voyage previous month.<ref name="Johnson"/> The [[Blue Origin NS-22|sixth crewed flight]] took place on 4 August 2022.

=== New Glenn ===
{{Main|New Glenn}}<!-- new article undergoing rapid change on September 12, 2016; soon will be much more there, and this article can scale back the orbital/New Glenn text a bit.  N2e -->

New Glenn is a {{convert|23|ft|order=flip|adj=on|0|sp=us}}-diameter [[multistage rocket|two-stage]] [[orbital spaceflight|orbital]] [[launch vehicle]] that is expected to launch no earlier than Q4 2023.<ref name="sn-20220323">{{cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |url=https://spacenews.com/vulcan-centaur-on-schedule-for-first-launch-in-2022-as-new-glenn-slips/ |title=Vulcan Centaur on schedule for first launch in 2022 as New Glenn slips |work=[[SpaceNews]] |date=March 23, 2022 |access-date=March 24, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=New Glenn |url=https://www.blueorigin.com/new-glenn/ |access-date=November 3, 2022|website=Blue Origin |language=en }}</ref>

The design work on the vehicle began in 2012. The high-level specifications for the vehicle were publicly announced in September 2016.<ref name="nsf20160912">{{Cite news |last=Bergin |first=Chris |date=September 12, 2016 |title=Blue Origin introduce the New Glenn orbital LV |work=[[NASASpaceFlight.com]] |url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2016/09/blue-origin-new-glenn-orbital-lv/ |url-status=live |access-date=September 12, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160913152524/https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2016/09/blue-origin-new-glenn-orbital-lv/ |archive-date=September 13, 2016}}</ref>

The first stage will be powered by seven [[BE-4]] engines, also designed and manufactured by Blue Origin. The first stage is [[reusable launch vehicle|reusable]], just like the [[New Shepard]] suborbital launch vehicle that preceded it. The second stage is intended to be [[expendable launch vehicle|expendable]].<ref name=nsf20160912/>

Blue Origin intends to launch the rocket from [[Cape Canaveral Launch Complex 36]], and manufacture the rockets at a new facility<!-- being built after 2015 --> on nearby land in [[Exploration Park]]. [[Acceptance testing]] of the BE-4 engines will also be done in [[Florida]].<ref name="cbs20150915">[https://www.cbsnews.com/news/bezos-announces-new-booster-florida-rocket-plant/ Jeff Bezos plans to boost humans into space from Cape Canaveral] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822010457/http://www.cbsnews.com/news/bezos-announces-new-booster-florida-rocket-plant/|date=August 22, 2016}}, ''CBS News'', accessed September 17, 2015. Bezos: "''You cannot afford to be a space-fairing civilization if you throw the rocket away every time you use it... We have to be focused on reusability, we have to be focused on lowering the cost of space''".</ref>

==== Orbital subsystems and earlier development work ====
Blue Origin began developing systems for [[Orbital mechanics|orbital]] human [[spacecraft]] prior to 2012. A reusable first-stage booster was projected to fly a suborbital trajectory, taking off vertically like the booster stage of a conventional multistage rocket. Following stage separation, the upper stage would continue to propel astronauts to orbit while the first-stage booster would descend to perform a powered vertical landing similar to the [[New Shepard]] [[Sub-orbital spaceflight|suborbital]] Propulsion Module. The first-stage booster would be refueled and launched again, allowing improved reliability and lowering the cost of human access to space.<ref name="Blue Origin – About Blue" />

The booster rocket was projected to loft Blue Origin's biconic Space Vehicle to orbit, carrying astronauts and supplies. After orbiting the Earth, the Space Vehicle will reenter Earth's atmosphere to land on land under parachutes, and then be reused on future missions to Earth orbit.<ref name="Blue Origin – About Blue" />

Blue Origin successfully completed a [[System Requirements Review]] (SRR) of its orbital Space Vehicle in May 2012.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin Completes Spacecraft System Requirements Review |url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2012/05/31/blue-origin-completes-spacecraft-system-requirements-review/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130527144321/http://www.parabolicarc.com/2012/05/31/blue-origin-completes-spacecraft-system-requirements-review/ |archive-date=May 27, 2013 |access-date=April 5, 2013}}</ref>

Engine testing for the [[Reusable Booster System]] (RBS) vehicle began in 2012. A full-power test of the thrust chamber for Blue Origin [[BE-3]] [[liquid oxygen]], [[liquid hydrogen]] [[rocket engine]] was conducted at a [[John C. Stennis Space Center|NASA test facility]] in October 2012. The chamber successfully achieved full thrust of {{convert|100000|lbf|kN|disp=x| (about |)|lk=out}}.<ref name="nsw20121016">{{Cite news |date=October 16, 2012 |title=Blue Origin tests 100k lb LOX/LH2 engine in commercial crew program |work=NewSpace Watch |url=http://newspacewatch.com/articles/blue-origin-tests-100k-lb-loxlh2-engine-in-commercial-crew-program.html |url-access=subscription |access-date=October 17, 2012}}</ref>

=== New Armstrong ===
<!-- please do NOT delete this section because New Armstrong redirects to this section -->
At the time of the announcement of [[New Glenn]] in 2016, [[Jeff Bezos]] revealed that the next project after [[New Glenn]] would be called New Armstrong, without detailing what that would be. Media have speculated that New Armstrong would be a launch vehicle named after [[Neil Armstrong]], the first man to walk on the Moon.<ref name="LATimes-2016-09-12">{{Cite news |last=Samantha Masunaga |date=September 12, 2016 |title=Blue Origin's new, more powerful rocket will compete with SpaceX |work=Los Angeles Times |url=https://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-blue-origin-rocket-20160912-snap-story.html |url-status=live |access-date=September 16, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160917030851/http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-blue-origin-rocket-20160912-snap-story.html |archive-date=September 17, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin releases details of its monster orbital rocket |date=March 7, 2017 |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2017/03/blue-origin-releases-details-of-its-monster-orbital-rocket/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190823142704/https://arstechnica.com/science/2017/03/blue-origin-releases-details-of-its-monster-orbital-rocket/ |archive-date=August 23, 2019 |access-date=August 24, 2019}}</ref>

=== ''Blue Moon'' ===
The ''[[Blue Moon (spacecraft)|Blue Moon]]'' lander is a [[human spaceflight|crew-carrying]] [[lunar lander]] unveiled in 2019.<ref name=cnbc20190509/> The standard version of the lander is intended to [[space transport|transport]] {{Convert|3.6|tonnes|lb|abbr=on}} to the lunar surface whereas a "stretched tank variant" could land up to {{Convert|6.5|tonnes|lb|abbr=on}} on the [[Moon]], both making a soft landing. The lander will use the [[#BE-7|BE-7]] [[hydrolox]] engine.<ref name=sfn20190509/>

=== Project Jarvis ===
Information became public in July 2021 that in recent months Blue Origin had begun a "project to develop a fully reusable upper stage for New Glenn."<ref name=ars20210727/> A principal goal of the project is to reduce the overall launch cost of [[New Glenn]] by gaining an operational capacity to reuse second stages, just as [[SpaceX]] is aiming to do with their [[Starship second stage]] by building a [[fully-reusable orbital launch vehicle]]. Jarvis is focusing on developing a [[stainless steel]] propellant tank structure for the second stage rocket, and evaluating it as a part of a solution for a complete second stage system.<ref name=ars20210824/> If Blue Origin is able to realize such a second stage design, and bring it into operational use, it would substantially bring down the cost of launches of the [[New Glenn]] system.<ref name=ars20210727>{{cite news |title=Blue Origin has a secret project named "Jarvis" to compete with SpaceX |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/blue-origin-is-developing-reusable-second-stage-other-advanced-projects/ |last=Berger|first=Eric |work=[[Ars Technica]] |date=27 July 2021 |access-date=31 July 2021}}</ref>

Beyond the technical changes indicated, CEO Bezos has created a new management structure for Project Jarvis, walling off "parts of the second-stage development program from the rest of Blue Origin [telling] its leaders to innovate in an environment unfettered by rigorous management and paperwork processes."<ref name=ars20210727/> No budget nor timetable has been publicly released.

On 24 August 2021, Blue Origin had rolled a [[stainless steel]] test tank to their [[Launch Complex 36]] facility. Ground [[pressure]] testing<!-- with [[Cryogenics|cyrogenic]] [[propellant]]s--> was expected to begin as early as September 2021, but this has not happened yet.<ref name=ars20210824>{{cite news |title=First images of Blue Origin's "Project Jarvis" test tank |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/08/first-images-of-blue-origins-project-jarvis-test-tank/ |last=Berger|first=Eric |work=[[Ars Technica]] |date=24 August 2021 |access-date=25 August 2021}}</ref>

=== Orbital Reef ===
On October 25, 2021, Blue Origin announced that together with [[Sierra Nevada Corporation|Sierra Space]] it would build a "Mixed-use space business park" in [[Low Earth orbit|LEO]] called [[Orbital Reef]], to "open multiple new markets in space, [and] provide anyone with the opportunity to establish their own address on orbit." It "will offer research, industrial, international, and [[Private spaceflight|commercial customers]] the cost competitive end-to-end services they need including space transportation and logistics, [[Human presence in space|space habitation]], equipment accommodation, and operations including onboard crew. The station will start operating in the second half of this decade."<ref>
{{Cite web
 | title= Blue Origin and Sierra Space developing commercial space station
 | website= Blue Origin / News
 | url= https://www.blueorigin.com/news/orbital-reef-commercial-space-station
 | access-date= 2022-02-24
}}
</ref>
Further partners are [[Boeing]], [[Redwire|Redwire Space]], [[Genesis Engineering Solutions]], and [[Arizona State University]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://orbitalreef.com/|title=Orbital Reef|website=Orbital Reef}}</ref>

== Rocket engines ==
Following Aerojet's acquisition of [[Pratt & Whitney Rocketdyne]] in 2012, Blue Origin president [[Rob Meyerson]] saw an opportunity to fill a gap in the defense industrial base. Blue Origin publicly entered the [[liquid propellant|liquid]] [[rocket engine]] business by partnering with ULA on the development of the [[BE-4]], and working with other companies. Meyerson announced the selection of [[Huntsville, Alabama]] as the location of Blue Origin's rocket production factory in June 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |title=BLUE ORIGIN OPENS UP |url=http://bt.e-ditionsbyfry.com/article/BLUE+ORIGIN+OPENS+UP/2384731/289258/article.html |access-date=May 6, 2021 |website=bt.e-ditionsbyfry.com |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Berger |first=Eric |date=June 28, 2017 |title=Why is Jeff Bezos building rocket engines in Alabama? He's playing to win |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2017/06/heres-why-jeff-bezos-is-building-rocket-engines-in-alabama/ |access-date=May 6, 2021 |website=Ars Technica |language=en-us}}</ref>

=== BE-1 ===
Blue Engine 1, or BE-1, was the first rocket engine developed by Blue Origin and was used on the company's [[Blue Origin Goddard|Goddard]] development vehicle. The [[pressure-fed engine|pressure-fed]] [[Monopropellant rocket|monopropellant]] engine was powered by [[High-test peroxide|peroxide]] and produced {{convert|2200|lbf|kN||abbr=on|order=flip}} of thrust.<ref name="BlueEngines">{{Cite web |title=Blue Origin Engines |url=https://www.blueorigin.com/engines |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612140938/https://www.blueorigin.com/engines |archive-date=June 12, 2018 |access-date=May 15, 2018 |publisher=Blue Origin}}</ref><ref name="BlueEngineChart">{{Cite tweet |number=972501472440213504 |user=jeff_foust |title=Rob Meyerson shows this chart of the various engines Blue Origin has developed and the vehicle that have used, or will use, them. #spaceexploration |date=March 10, 2018}}</ref>

=== BE-2 ===
Blue Engine 2, or BE-2, was a [[turbopump|pump-fed]] bipropellant engine burning [[RP-1|kerosene]] and [[High-test peroxide|peroxide]] which produced {{convert|31000|lbf|kN||abbr=on|order=flip}} of thrust.<ref name="BlueEngines" /><ref name = BlueEngineChart/> Five BE-2 engines powered Blue Origin's PM-2 development vehicle on two test flights in 2011.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Krebs |first=Gunter |date=April 29, 2018 |title=New Shepard |url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_lau_fam/new-shepard.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180516015221/http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_lau_fam/new-shepard.htm |archive-date=May 16, 2018 |access-date=May 15, 2018 |website=Gunter's Space Page}}</ref>

=== BE-3 ===
{{Main|BE-3}}
Blue Origin publicly announced the development of the Blue Engine 3, or BE-3, in January 2013, but the engine had begun [[New product development|development]] in the early 2010s.  BE-3 is a new [[liquid hydrogen]]/[[liquid oxygen]] (LH2/LOX) cryogenic engine that can produce {{convert|110000|lbf|kN||abbr=on|order=flip}} of thrust at full power, and can be [[Rocket engine throttling|throttled down]] to as low as {{convert|25000|lbf|kN|abbr=on|order=flip}} for use in controlled [[VTVL|vertical landings]].<ref name=pa20131203/>

Early thrust chamber testing began at NASA Stennis<ref name="nsj20130117">{{Cite news |date=January 17, 2013 |title=Updates on commercial crew development |work=NewSpace Journal |url=http://www.newspacejournal.com/2013/01/17/updates-on-commercial-crew-development/ |url-status=live |access-date=January 21, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130119091227/http://www.newspacejournal.com/2013/01/17/updates-on-commercial-crew-development/ |archive-date=January 19, 2013}}</ref>
in 2013.<ref name=pa20131203vid/><!-- the NASA Kennedy video (released in Dec 2013) of full-duration flight tests "mission duty cycle tests" in Texas refers to the "thrust chamber was successfully tested at NASA's Stennis Space Center in Missippii", but doesn't say WHEN the tests were actually run. -->

By late 2013, the BE-3 had been successfully tested on a full-duration suborbital burn, with simulated coast phases and engine relights, "demonstrating deep throttle, full power, long-duration and [[Rocket engine restart|reliable restart]] all in a single-test sequence."<ref name="pa20131203">{{Cite news |last=Messier |first=Doug |date=December 3, 2013 |title=Blue Origin Tests New Engine in Simulated Suborbital Mission Profile |work=Parabolic Arc |url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2013/12/03/blue-origin-tests-engine-simulated-suborbital-mission-profile/ |url-status=live |access-date=December 5, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206020133/http://www.parabolicarc.com/2013/12/03/blue-origin-tests-engine-simulated-suborbital-mission-profile/ |archive-date=December 6, 2013}}</ref>
NASA has released a video of the test.<ref name="pa20131203vid">{{Cite news |last=Messier |first=Doug |date=December 3, 2013 |title=Video of Blue Origin Engine Test |work=Parabolic Arc |url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2013/12/03/video-blue-origin-engine-test/ |url-status=live |access-date=December 5, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206023638/http://www.parabolicarc.com/2013/12/03/video-blue-origin-engine-test/ |archive-date=December 6, 2013}}</ref>
{{asof|2013|12}}, the engine had demonstrated more than 160 starts and {{convert|9100|s|h}} of operation at Blue Origin's test facility near [[Van Horn, Texas]].<ref name=pa20131203/><ref>[http://aviationweek.com/awin/blue-origin-tests-new-engine Blue Origin Tests New Engine] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108122553/http://aviationweek.com/awin/blue-origin-tests-new-engine |date=January 8, 2016 }}, ''Aviation Week'', 2013-12-09, accessed September 16, 2014.</ref>

BE-3 engine [[acceptance testing]] was completed by April 2015 with 450 test firings of the engine and a cumulative run time of more than {{Convert|30000|seconds|h}}. The BE-3 engine powers the [[Blue Origin New Shepard|New Shepard]] [[space capsule]] that is being used for Blue Origin [[suborbital spaceflight|suborbital]] flights that began in 2015.<ref name=tsr20150413/>

==== BE-3U ====
The BE-3U engine is a modified BE-3 for use on [[upper stage]]s of Blue Origin [[orbital spaceflight|orbital]] [[launch vehicle]]s.  The engine will include a [[Rocket engine expansion|nozzle better optimized]] for operation under [[vacuum (outer space)|vacuum]] conditions as well as a number of other manufacturing differences since it is an expendable engine whereas the BE-3 is designed for reusability.<ref name="nsj20131207">{{Cite news |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=December 7, 2013 |title=Blue Origin shows off its engine |work=NewSpace Journal |url=http://www.newspacejournal.com/2013/12/07/blue-origin-shows-off-its-engine/ |url-status=live |access-date=December 10, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214062226/http://www.newspacejournal.com/2013/12/07/blue-origin-shows-off-its-engine/ |archive-date=December 14, 2013}}</ref>

=== BE-4 ===
{{Main|BE-4}}
[[File:Blue Origin BE-4 rocket engine, sn 103, April 2018 -- LCH4 inlet side view.jpg|thumb|BE-4 rocket engine, on display at the 34th Space Symposium, April 2018. It was the first BE-4 to be hotfire tested, on October 18, 2017.]]
Blue Origin began work on a new and much larger rocket engine in 2011.  The new engine, the ''Blue Engine 4'', or ''BE-4'', is a change for Blue Origin in that it is their first engine that will combust [[liquid oxygen]] and [[liquid methane]] [[rocket propellant|propellants]].  The engine has been designed to produce {{convert|550000|lbf|kN|order=flip|lk=on|abbr=on}} of thrust, and was initially planned to be used exclusively on a Blue Origin proprietary launch vehicle.  Blue Origin did not announce the new engine to the public until September 2014.<ref name=sn20140917/>

In late 2014, Blue Origin signed an agreement with [[United Launch Alliance]] (ULA) to co-develop the BE-4 engine, and to commit to use the new engine on an [[Atlas V#Replacement with Vulcan|upgraded]] [[Atlas V]] launch vehicle, replacing the single [[RD-180]] Russian-made engine. The [[Atlas V successor|new launch vehicle]] will use two of the {{convert|550000|lbf|kN|order=flip|lk=on|abbr=on}} BE-4 engines on each [[first stage (rocketry)|first stage]].
